project.title: Beyond the Batey: Analyzing Historical and Contemporary Bomba Performances and Films
project.description: For this digital edition/exhibit, I have created annotations for audiovisual elements for commercial music videos featuring bomba, for various largescale bomba festivals including La magia de los tambores, Los Encuentros de Tambores, Los Encuentros de Cantaoras, and LaSanse.
project.creator: lexirosev16

A flamenco singer accompanies images and text that state: “La bomba y la plena son productos de fusiones musicales de la taína, la española y la africana, un ir y venir de influencias. Esta influencia afectaría toda la vida de esta isla.” Musical lyrics are mostly unintelligible during this segment.
Bomba and plena are the products of musical fusions of Taíno, Spanish, and African traditions—an ebb and flow of influences. This influence would shape the entire life of the island.
Vocalist Lucecita Benitez sings a part of "Una Noche En Borinquen" from her album
A song which discusses a Black woman who loses her love and suffers due to this loss.
Negra triste, porque ya el negro murió, porque ya el negro durmió, mas nunca va a disfrutar el guateque— solo quedó la negra.
La negra no cesa de llorar, ¡ay, su dolor! Negra está triste, negra sola llora su pena, llora su pena y su dolor.
El negro que tanto quiso está en los reinos de Dios. Negra está triste, está llorando su amor, está llorando a su negro, su negro que tanto amó.
Sad Black woman, because the Black man has died, because the Black man has slept, never again to enjoy the celebration— only the Black woman remains.
She does not stop crying, oh, her sorrow. She is sad, alone she weeps her grief, she weeps her sorrow and her pain.
The Black man she loved so deeply is now in the realms of God. She is heartbroken, mourning her love, mourning her Black man, the one she loved so much.

Welmo E. Romero-Joseph (b. 1993) was a hip-hop MC, who is also known for his activism and values of social justice. In this clip, he sings in Spanish, rapping the following:
Presuemiendo que mi gente se encuentre lista llega un cronista, protagonista de una historia
que le rinde culto al ritmo el tambor y la cadencia
dando esencia y vigencia a fuertes memorias
reclamando un espacio al interior de una cultura que en ocasiones ha olvidado el espelendor de su negrura.

“Assuming my people are ready, a chronicler arrives—protagonist of a story
that pays homage to rhythm, to the drum and its cadence,
giving essence and vitality to powerful memories,
reclaiming a space within a culture that at times
has forgotten the splendor of its Blackness.
Final credits roll on the screen and state the following:
A production of paradise films and ninguen sciencia

To open the film, a bomba song begins with a yubá rhythm. The song is “Estoy buscando un árbol que me dé sombra. The traditional tune then transitions into a salsa adaptation, signaling musical fusion. The accompanying image of the film depicts bomba practitioners or bomberos/bomberas playing the barriles (bomba drums), dancing, depict a traditional casita, and show a tree growing, and its roots and seeds as fertilizing the earth.

An electric guitar transitions into “Cuembe na’ma,” a bomba song presented here with a salsa-fusion adaptation. Flamenco singer Olga Tañón (A Puerto Rican singer known as the "Queen of Merengue" performs, accompanied by palmas (handclaps), while a bomba dancer is present. Traditional
are heard, along with interruptions from the barriles, creating a call-and-response between the palmas and the drums. Additional lyrics not originally part of

The clips showcases highly virtuosic singing. The batey (or space in which bomba is performed) is located at an outdoor location and used modern sound equipment. Mar Anthony also has a small solo during this performance segment. Giovanni Hidalgo is on the barriles.
Soy de la calle y la puerta de atrás
Aquí todo el mundo quiere gozar
Ya sé que ésta es mi gente
El humo de un joy me hace volar
Aquí no hay noches ni día
aquí no hay noches ni día, nos reiremos
sé que todo en esta vida pasará
tan agustito, tan agustito, tú ves
Variation of original lyrics serves a narrative function

Para que sepas en verdad quién soy, de dónde vengo y hacia dónde voy. Voy a contarte una historia, lo que debe saber la sangre que corre. Mis pedazas es pura cera, te dire porque. (Llamada)"que ataca a José"

Welmo intervenes once again with a narrative rap transition. His rap declares: No pretendo ser el reemplazo de voces ausentes, ni decir que mi oratoria es la única referencia. Baile bomba, toques de plena—lo que digo vale la pena. Lo importante es la conexión del pasado con el presente.
I don’t pretend to replace absent voices, nor claim that my speech is the only reference. Dance bomba, play plena—what I say is worth hearing. What matters is the connection between past and present.

1950s recording which transitions into a professional commercial recording of Paracumbé with lead singer Nelie Robles Lebron from 1997.

Welmo raps: Me levanto tomo aire sigo el ritmo me despejo en la sangre de una raza que se mira al espejo con las manos negras manos que se lanzan sobre el cuero. Canto, baile, ritmo. Canto, baile, ritmo.
I rise, I breathe, I follow the rhythm. I clear my mind in the blood of a race that looks into the mirror with Black hands—hands that strike the drum. Song, dance, rhythm. Song, dance, rhythm.

La sensación del gusto, el roce de la tela y el sudor pasean juntos. Aumentan los latidos, temperatura en fiebre que le curó. No se calle, pues si callo no soy libre. Llamando y respuesta, resistencia y osadía, Aun con las cadenas, 24 horas al día. Mi voz viaja activa, sabiendo que quizás No vuelva a ver la luz del día. Tambor, dame el ser del sonido de tu alma. Tambor, cuida mi sueño con tu dulce melodía.

The sensation of taste, the brush of fabric, and sweat walk together. Heartbeats rise, fevered temperature healed. Do not be silent—for if I am silent, I am not free. Call and response, resistance and boldness, Even with chains, 24 hours a day. My voice travels, alive, Knowing that perhaps I may never see the light of day again. Drum, give me the being of your soul’s sound. Drum, guard my sleep with your sweet melody

Vives en tu vida que a tu modo mis maneras y por eso nena se cortaron sin problemas. Elenas mueren cada día por maltrato a un con nueve o sigo la ley 54.

Images of hip-hop or breakdance occurring in a batey

The vocalist is uncredited in the film but the style resembles that of Residente/Calle 13. The singer might also be the rapper-singer Welmo who appears throughout the film. In this segment, an electric guitar melody can be heard, and it transitions into the following partial song. The song "soy libre" of unknown author is political in nature commenting on the nature of freedom, and colonialism in Puerto Rico by stating that the author is "free like the rivers." It's a powerful close to a film that touches on themes colonialism rather sparingly.
Y soy libre, Libre como el río que en el mar desemboca
Libre las palabras que saltan de mi boca. Libre decido y alcanzo lo que quiero, Y aunque presto esté mi cuerpo

Es mi mente la que elevo. Libre es el aire que respiro Desde el momento en que nazco Hasta el último suspiro. Libre como el suelo de una isla que se expande, Libre es mi pueblo, y ante balas no se rinde

Amo, los esclavistas trataban de agrupar en una plantación a personas que venían de África, de distintos lugares en África, de tal manera que no pudieran hablar entre sí. Ellos traían su religión, traían su música, traían todo. Y entonces, claro, muchas gente se comunicaban más a través de una forma que sí comparten distintas regiones, géneros rítmicos, formas de comunicación este corporal.
Pues mira, tenían que sacar toda esa furia, todo ese coraje, todo ese sentimiento. ¿Cómo lo hacían? Se reunían los sábados en la noche, en los cañaverales, escondida de los capataces a bailar bomba.

Ayer yo estaba en la Bomba, en casa Rosa Inés, pidiendo toditos golpe, y Plere Maria, pleré.
Ya llegaba Eustacio Flores, y llegaba Andres Laguer, y estuvo Papo y le dice Plere María, pleré.
Ya llega Gloria a la puerta, y llega a la fiesta Belén, cantando coros y alegre, fiesta todos Pleré Belén.

Yo no feliz vivir aquí. Yo no feliz vivir aquí, yo lo pedí óyeme bien.
Tanta indecencia, tanta indecencia, tanta indecencia.

Me sacaron de mi tierra, que cadenas me llevaron.
Ni mi hermana o mi hermano pude ver.
A la amigazos me humillaron, y mi piel ellos marcaron.
Solo a la caña le cantaba mi querer.

Yo no feliz vivir aquí, yo no feliz vivir aquí, yo no feliz, óyeme bien.
Tanta indecencia.

Mi nombre me cambiaron, y otro dios me presentaron.

Estaba toda mi historia,
Y fui libre una vez y lo seré.

Yo no feliz vivir aquí,
Yo no feliz vivir aquí,
Yo no feliz vivir aquí.
Tanta indecencia,

El mayoral me castigaba,
Sangre y sudor me empapaba.
Pero mi alma, siempre libre, quiso ser.
La dignidad y el coraje hacia él.
Donde me llevaron era la muerte
O la libertad de mi ser.

Yo no feliz vivir aquí,

Desde Chicago, Puerto Rico se la dedico

Entonces le dije: “Gracias, muy amable es usted

De mis ancestros y del sonido de mi tambor

Mi raza es mi color, y de ella orgullosa estoy

Ahí, ¿y qué pasa si me coges con otro?

Context: This segment of Zafra depicts the tri-ethnic heritage of Puerto Ricans. It includes scenes from the plantations, scenes involving enslavement, and scenes depicting Christopher Colombus.....

La bomba no es solo música,
es la tierra hecha sonido,
un latido que llegó de África
y floreció en Puerto Rico.

Un diálogo entre tambor, cuerpo y la voz colectiva,
cada paso y cada golpe en el tambor
nos recuerda que estamos conectados
con el pasado y con el futuro.

Una tradición nacida de la resistencia,
que hoy sigue siendo una celebración de la libertad.
Cada pueblo de Puerto Rico
expresa la bomba a su manera.

Los ritmos laten en la arena,
un diálogo improvisado donde el cuerpo ordena
y la música obedece.

Los ritmos se mezclan con el carnaval
y la energía del pueblo.
Los vejigantes, mitad enigmáticos,
tallados por artesanos y pintados con colores vibrantes,
no son disfraces,
son espíritus del Caribe.

Despiertan la memoria ancestral de nuestro pueblo,
son guardianes de la cultura,
símbolos de resistencia que encarnan
la eterna batalla contra lo oscuro.

En cada máscara arde la fuerza de un pueblo
que transforma el miedo en poder
y la lucha en celebración.

El baile de bomba es fuerza, tensión y libertad.
La bomba es unión:
une a pueblos y a generaciones,
orgullo cultural afro-boricua.

Cuando el ritmo llama,
toda la comunidad responde.
Qué bendición lo que estoy viendo
La luz en tu piel me está pidiendo
Ma, tú no entiendes cuánto tú me gustas
Cuando bajas, me subes al cielo
Una vida sin ti yo no quiero
Pensar en no tenerte me asusta, eh
Por to lo que se vivió
Y si este momento nunca vuelve
Ey, mami, tu alma es libre como primavera
Pa nuestro amor no existe frontera
Amarrao a ti como cuero y madera
Baila, que el calor te suelte la tela
No nos vamos hasta que los pies nos duelan
Tierra prometida, quieres que me quede
El agua de tu flor hace que yo me eleve
Se me cierra hasta el pecho
El día que no estés que nunca llegue
Si tú te vas, que el fuego me queme
Ma, tú no entiendes cuánto tú me gustas
Cuando bajas, me subes al cielo
Una vida sin ti yo no quiero
Pensar en no tenerte me asusta, eh
Por to lo que se vivió
Y si este momento nunca vuelve
Coqui sounds, thunder, and rain are heard as final credits roll. (soundscape)
All female bomba group playing at a bar in Rio Piedras.
EBPDCB is depicted. Cary Cepeda instructs classes in Viejo San Juan
Cary Cepeda discusses the suffering, and labor required of carrying on the legacy of bomba. They had to carry heavy drums very far to neighboring towns.
Don Rafael Cepeda discusses his grandfather.
Marien Torres discusses joining the bomba ensemble Plenibom in college led by Norma Salazar and being arrested for protesting in 1999.
Diegetic saxophone music plays as images of La Fortaleza in Viejo San Juan are shown

At Museo de San Juan, Marien Torres’ dance classes present a re-enactment of the Vieques military occupation protests. The choreography explores the tension and resistance of that historic moment: some dancers embody military figures, their arms rigidly posed like rifles, while others portray the resisters. Through movement, the dancers evoke the emotional and political struggle of the protests, transforming the studio into a living archive of Puerto Rican resistance.
Diegetic saxophone music plays as Hurricane Maria and past news clips are shown
Diegetic music plays as images of the ocean and the town Mayaguez plays
Cary Cepeda discusses her family history and legacy.

Discussion of political corruption. Videos of politicians are shown
Marien discusses the lack of self-governance in Puerto Rico
Song about hurricane Maria plays as images of someone's music production studio and audio editing software are shown
More diegetic saxophone and piano music is played

Marien Torres discusses the impact of Puerto Rico's soundscape which consisted of chicken cries that changed after hurricane Maria and also how even these animals exemplify resilience. She also discusses how the water flooded her house and her new house which is quite empty
Marrien Torres discusses how she had to make changes to her quality of living to continue paying for her daughter's education and to continue paying her bomba instructors.
Protests discussing the wages in Puerto Rico.
In a car ride, Marien discussed civil rights, bomba, and gender issues.
Generational changes. The new generation has it a little easier than the last. If they did not teach, they knew it would not continue.
performed by the Delegation de Loiza
Delegation of the Diaspora. Ivelisse Dias of La Escuelita de Bombera Corazon presents a solo.
Diegetic saxophone music plays while Marien Torres discusses the trenches, cultural labor, and the values of resilience inherent to bomba and creating spaces for healing.
Chickens and baby chickens appear on screen to close alluding to hope, as their presence was discussed by Marien Torres earlier in the film
Discusses the significance of the maraca to cantos de bomba.

children.text: This section contains audiovisual recordings from los encuentros de tambores y cantaoras held between 2022 and 2025. In this section, I have transcribed the song lyrics, identified and tagged the performers and composers, and coded the material according to lyrical analysis. The overarching themes include race, gender, nation, oppression, and related social dynamics.

Alexis R. Velazquez's AVAnnotate project “Beyond the Batey: Analyzing Historical and Contemporary Bomba Performances” contains two sets of annotations. A Translation of the film "Zafra: Fusion Familia Cepeda 1983," and a second set of annotations identifying bomba songs, lyrics, instrumentation, rhythms, and performers with assistance from community consultants and bomba practitioners, Jonas Martinez, Miguel Stevens, William Miranda, and Barbara Cepeda.

children.text: There are eight delegations that perform in the Encuentro de Tambores. These include the Delegation(s) of Oeste, Loiza, Diaspora, Cangrejos, Sur, Norte, Este, and [add]. Approximately, 800 bomberos perform in this event held annually on [add dates]. The event was founded by Norma Salazar [add context] and in [add year] was taken over by Marrien Torres of [add group affiliation].

c04e4495-9fe8-45eb-a738-9f38a03b882f.title: Los Encuentros de Tambores y Cantaoras

children.text: This AVannotate audiovisual project centers on bomba, an Afro-Puerto Rican music - dance tradition. It features annotated events from
, spanning from 2022 to 2024. The project also includes three films relevant to bomba culture:

(2001). In addition, it incorporates recordings from notable festivals such as La Sanse, IMMERSE, and La Magia de los Tambores. The project houses transcriptions that emphasize themes of poverty, resistance, oppression, colonialism, and politics. Each annotation is enriched with metadata tags for instrumentation, genre, performers, speakers, and context. Designed within the AVannotate platform, this project aims to support bomba practitioners and amateur scholars interested in Afro-Caribbean expressive and musical culture. Most audiovisual materials are sourced from YouTube.
